deliberation: Considered whether the eating command is literal within a vision or figurative. In prophetic literature, eating a scroll is a symbolic enactment of internalizing God's message. Also noted 'House of Israel' as a conventional metonymy for the people.

instances.hebrew_text: אֵת אֲשֶׁר־תִּמְצָא אֱכֹול אֱכֹל אֶת־הַמְּגִלָּה הַזֹּאת
instances.english_text: Eat what is offered you; eat this scroll
target: prophetic commissioning / inner reception of revelation
ground: internalizing and assimilating something so it becomes part of oneself
instances.explanation: The act of eating a scroll symbolizes Ezekiel's internalization of God's message, treating the words like food taken into his very being.

instances.english_text: the House of Israel
target: the people of Israel (especially the exilic community)
vehicle: a 'house' as a household or dynasty
ground: unity and corporate identity under one 'house'
instances.explanation: 'House of Israel' uses 'house' as a metonym for the entire people/nation as one corporate family.

deliberation: This continues the visionary eating of the scroll. Within the narrative world the act happens, but its meaning is symbolic of receiving the word, so it functions as an enacted metaphor.

instances.hebrew_text: וָאֶפְתַּח אֶת־פִּי וַיַּאֲכִילֵנִי אֵת הַמְּגִלָּה הַזֹּאת
instances.english_text: So I opened my mouth, and I was given this scroll to eat
target: Ezekiel's reception of and submission to the prophetic message
vehicle: opening the mouth and being fed a scroll as if it were food
ground: passive, receptive taking-in of something provided
being filled with what one is given
instances.explanation: Ezekiel's being fed the scroll enacts the metaphor of God's word as food that fills and sustains the prophet's inner being.

deliberation: Verse combines the continued 'eating the scroll' imagery (metaphor for internalizing God's word) with an explicit taste comparison 'like honey' (simile). Considered whether 'belly'/'inner parts' are figurative; they support the main ingestion metaphor, not a separate figure.

instances.hebrew_text: בִּטְנְךָ תַּאֲכֵל וּמֵעֶיךָ תְמַלֵּא אֵת הַמְּגִלָּה הַזֹּאת
instances.english_text: Feed your stomach and fill your belly with this scroll
target: Ezekiel's total internalization of God's message
vehicle: stomach and intestines filled with eaten scroll
ground: complete, inward assimilation of what is taken in
having something occupy and sustain one's inner being
posture: willing, thorough acceptance of God's word
instances.explanation: The scroll is treated as food that fills Ezekiel's inner organs, picturing the word as something he must ingest until it permeates his whole inner life.

instances.english_text: it tasted as sweet as honey to me
ground: enjoyable quality intense enough to be compared with sweet taste
posture: positive enjoyment of God's word despite its hard content
instances.explanation: The simile likens the experience of receiving God's word to tasting honey, emphasizing its sweetness and desirability.

deliberation: The verse is mainly straightforward command. The only potentially figurative element is 'House of Israel' as a metonymy for the people.

instances.english_text: to the House of Israel
target: the Israelite people, especially the exiles
vehicle: a 'house' as a kinship unit or dynasty
ground: shared identity and unity under one 'roof' or lineage
posture: covenantal naming that recalls family relationship with God
instances.explanation: Again 'house' stands for the entire community as one corporate family, a metonymic way of referring to the nation.

deliberation: Examined 'deep of lip' and 'heavy of tongue'—Hebrew idiom for obscure/difficult language, with physical-weight imagery applied to speech. Also 'House of Israel' as metonymy again.

instances.english_text: a people of unintelligible speech and difficult language (deep of lip and heavy of tongue)
target: foreign languages hard for Ezekiel to understand
vehicle: depth and weight applied to speech organs
spatial/physical properties of depth and heaviness
ground: hard to reach, hard to move, and therefore hard to understand or speak
posture: emphasizing that Ezekiel's task is not hindered by language barriers
instances.explanation: Depth and heaviness, normally physical properties, are mapped onto speech to describe it as obscure and hard to handle.

instances.english_text: to the House of Israel
target: Israel as the addressee of the prophecy
ground: one people under a common ancestral 'house'
posture: reminding of shared heritage and responsibility
instances.explanation: As elsewhere, 'house' names the entire people metonymically as one familial entity.

deliberation: Same idiom for obscure language as in verse 5, now applied to many nations. No additional clear figures beyond that.

instances.hebrew_text: עַמִּים רַבִּים עִמְקֵי שָׂפָה וְכִבְדֵי לָשׁוֹן
instances.english_text: many peoples of unintelligible speech and difficult language (deep of lip and heavy of tongue)
ground: speech that is hard to reach or move through, hence hard to understand
posture: emphasizing potential receptivity of foreign nations in contrast to Israel
instances.explanation: The same bodily-depth and heaviness imagery is used for language, forming an idiomatic metaphor for obscurity and difficulty.

deliberation: Detected (1) 'House of Israel' metonymy, (2) 'brazen of forehead' as metaphor for shameless stubbornness, (3) 'stubborn/hard of heart' as metaphor for inner obstinacy. 'Not willing to listen' is conventional obedience language but not treated here as a separate figure.

instances.english_text: the House of Israel
target: Israel as a collective moral subject
posture: frames Israel as a family responsible before God
instances.explanation: Again, 'house' stands for the people as one familial/national unit.

instances.english_text: brazen of forehead (strong of forehead)
target: Israel's shameless resistance to God's message
vehicle: a hard, unyielding forehead, like metal
ground: shameless refusal to bow or blush
instances.explanation: The hardness of the forehead pictures their brazen, unblushing refusal to heed rebuke.

instances.english_text: stubborn of heart (hard of heart)
ground: inability/unwillingness to be moved or softened
instances.explanation: The 'heart' is conceived as hardened, representing an inner life that refuses to be responsive to God.

deliberation: God promises to make Ezekiel's 'face' and 'forehead' hard against theirs. This extends the hardness metaphor, now applied positively to Ezekiel's resilience. Treated as one composite metaphor since the face/forehead imagery jointly conveys his strengthened resolve.

instances.hebrew_text: נָתַתִּי אֶת־פָּנֶיךָ חֲזָקִים לְעֻמַּת פְּנֵיהֶם וְאֶת־מִצְחֲךָ חָזָק לְעֻמַּת מִצְחָם
instances.english_text: I will make your face as hard as theirs, and your forehead as brazen as theirs
target: Ezekiel's psychological resilience before hostile hearers
vehicle: a hard, brazen face and forehead opposed to others
material properties of strength and rigidity
ground: unflinching, not easily intimidated or shamed
capacity to withstand opposition without yielding
posture: divine empowerment for a difficult mission
instances.explanation: God uses the same hardness imagery to describe the prophet's God-given firmness in the face of Israel's stubbornness.

deliberation: Identified (1) an explicit simile comparing Ezekiel's forehead to adamant harder than flint, continuing the hardness imagery; (2) 'house of rebellion' as a metonymic label for the people defined by their characteristic behavior.

instances.english_text: I will make your forehead like adamant, harder than flint
ground: unbreakable, resistant to impact or pressure
incapacity to be worn down by opposition
instances.explanation: By comparing his forehead to the hardest stone, God vividly portrays the prophet's divinely granted unyielding resolve.

instances.english_text: a rebellious house
target: Israel as a people characterized by rebellion
vehicle: family/dynasty whose defining trait is defiance
ground: shared collective behavior being the family's nickname
group defined by its prevailing characteristic
instances.explanation: The entire nation is labeled a 'rebellious house', using 'house' as metonym for the people and defining them by habitual rebellion.

deliberation: The key figure is 'take all my words in your heart', using 'heart' as the seat of thought and will and 'taking' them as internalization. 'With your ears hear' is literal, governing the metaphorical 'heart' command.

instances.english_text: receive into your mind (take in your heart) all the words
target: Ezekiel's cognitive and volitional grasp of God's words
ground: bringing something into one's inner core so it shapes identity and decisions
deep appropriation, not mere surface hearing
posture: urging attentive, deep engagement with God's speech
instances.explanation: The 'heart' is pictured as a container into which words can be taken, capturing the idea of deeply internalizing God's message.

deliberation: Looked for figurative elements. The notable expression is the paired clause 'whether they listen or whether they refrain', a set phrase covering both acceptance and rejection—a kind of merism-like rhetorical pair.

instances.english_text: whether they listen or not (whether they listen or whether they refrain)
target: all possible responses of the audience to the prophetic word
vehicle: binary pair of listening vs. refraining/ceasing
ground: encompassing the full range of possible attitudes by citing opposite ends
posture: underscoring that Ezekiel's duty is independent of response
instances.explanation: The contrasted pair 'listen / refrain' functions like a merismatic formula, summing up all responses to highlight Ezekiel's obligation regardless of outcome.

deliberation: Key figure is 'the spirit lifted me up', where ruach functions as an agent that can carry the prophet. This is either the divine Spirit or a wind personified. The acclamation 'Blessed be the glory of YHWH' is standard liturgical, not intrinsically figurative beyond metonymic 'glory', which is common but less central here.

instances.english_text: Then a spirit carried me away (the spirit lifted me up)
target: Ezekiel's being moved by divine power into a new situation
vehicle: a wind/spirit physically lifting and carrying a person
forceful movement by an invisible agent
ground: being seized and moved by a power beyond oneself
loss of control and relocation by external agency
posture: acknowledging God's overpowering initiative in his ministry
instances.explanation: The ruach is depicted as a lifting, carrying agent, personifying the Spirit and metaphorically describing Ezekiel's compelled movement by divine power.

deliberation: The description is largely concrete visionary imagery. The phrase 'each wing to her sister' uses kinship language for parts of the creatures, a mild metaphor/personification.

instances.english_text: the sound of the wings of the creatures beating against one another, each to her sister
target: the coordinated wing movements of the living creatures
vehicle: sisters in relation to one another
ground: closeness and pairing, belonging together in a set
posture: awe-struck descriptive stance, using familiar kinship to convey orderliness
attempt to make the vision relatable
instances.explanation: Calling one wing the 'sister' of another personifies the wings with kinship, highlighting their paired, coordinated motion.

deliberation: Found three notable figures: (1) 'spirit lifted me and took me' (as in v.12), (2) 'I went bitter, in the heat/fury of my spirit'—emotion described in taste and temperature terms, and (3) 'the hand of YHWH upon me' as idiom for overpowering divine control.

instances.english_text: A spirit seized me and carried me away
target: Ezekiel's forced transition under divine influence
vehicle: being seized and carried by a spirit/wind
physical abduction by an invisible agent
ground: lack of self-direction; overpowering external force moving him
posture: acknowledgement of divine mastery over his movements
instances.explanation: The spirit is personified as grabbing and carrying him, describing his experience of divine compulsion.

instances.english_text: I went in bitterness, in the fury (heat) of my spirit
vehicle: bitterness of taste and heat of anger within the spirit
ground: emotional pain and agitation felt as bitter and hot
posture: honest acknowledgement of turmoil despite obedience
instances.explanation: His emotional turmoil is mapped onto the sensory domains of bitter taste and burning heat, expressing the intensity of his feelings.

instances.english_text: while the hand of the LORD was strong upon me
target: God's powerful influence constraining and directing Ezekiel
vehicle: a strong hand pressing down upon someone
physical grip or weight of a hand
ground: control, pressure, and empowerment exerted on a person
being constrained and guided by superior strength
posture: portrays prophetic experience as heavy yet authoritative
instances.explanation: The 'hand of the LORD' is a conventional metaphor/idiom for God's overpowering, guiding presence on the prophet.

deliberation: The verse narrates Ezekiel's arrival and sitting stunned for seven days. 'Stunned' describes psychological shock; 'seven days' is a conventional mourning period but still literal. No clear figurative expressions stand out.

Looked at 'the word of the LORD came to me'—a fixed prophetic formula in which God's 'word' is treated as something that can come. This functions as a mild personification/metaphor for receiving revelation.

instances.english_text: the word of the LORD came to me, saying
target: the event of God communicating a message
vehicle: a 'word' as an entity that can come to someone
ground: a discrete, initiating encounter that reaches the prophet
revelation as something arriving from outside
posture: highlights prophetic passivity in origin of message
instances.explanation: The 'word' is depicted as an arriving agent, personifying the message and using spatial movement to express the onset of revelation.

deliberation: Two clear figures: (1) Ezekiel appointed as 'watchman' (tsopheh) for Israel—a central metaphor for his prophetic role, and (2) 'House of Israel' as metonymy for the people.

instances.english_text: I appoint you lookout (watchman) for the House of Israel
ground: vigilance, early detection of danger, and warning others
responsibility to sound alarm to protect community
posture: elevates but also burdens Ezekiel with grave responsibility
instances.explanation: His prophetic task is likened to a watchman who must stay alert and warn the city of coming danger, emphasizing vigilance and accountability.

instances.english_text: for the House of Israel
target: Israel as the object of Ezekiel's watchfulness
ground: corporate identity and shared fate under one 'house'
posture: emphasizes covenant family dimensions of Israel's accountability
instances.explanation: Again, 'house' stands metonymically for the whole people as one family to be guarded.

deliberation: Identified (1) 'his wicked way' as a standard path metaphor for one's manner of life, and (2) 'his blood I will require from your hand' as idiomatic metaphor for being held responsible for another's death.

instances.english_text: their wicked course (his wicked way)
target: the total pattern of a wicked person's conduct
ground: life as a path chosen and walked, leading to a destination
posture: highlights moral responsibility for chosen direction
frames sin as a path that can be left
instances.explanation: The Hebrew 'way' depicts a person's conduct as a path they walk, emphasizing directionality and the possibility of turning from it.

instances.english_text: while from you I will require a reckoning for their blood (his blood I will require from your hand)
target: Ezekiel's accountability for failing to warn
vehicle: seeking someone's blood from another's hand
blood on someone's hand as sign of guilt
ground: bearing responsibility for another's death as if one had shed their blood
instances.explanation: God uses the idiom of demanding a victim's blood from another's hand to portray Ezekiel's responsibility for failing to warn.

deliberation: Again we have (1) 'his wicked way' as path metaphor, and (2) 'you have saved your life/soul'—idiom where 'save your nefesh' means preserve yourself from guilt or death.

instances.english_text: and from their wicked course (his wicked way)
target: the habitual pattern of wicked conduct
ground: ongoing direction, with the possibility of turning aside
course leading to a particular end (death)
posture: emphasizes that warning seeks to change direction
instances.explanation: As in v.18, life conduct is portrayed as a path, reinforcing the conceptual metaphor LIFE-AS-JOURNEY for moral behavior.

instances.english_text: while you will have saved your own life (saved your soul)
target: Ezekiel's standing before God and ultimate well-being
vehicle: rescuing a living being from danger
ground: being delivered from liability that leads to death
posture: motivates obedience by linking it to one's own survival
instances.explanation: The idiom 'save your soul' uses rescue-from-death imagery to speak of avoiding guilt and judgment through faithful obedience.

deliberation: Detected multiple figures: (1) 'I put a stumbling block before him' as metaphor for divine means of downfall/occasion of sin/judgment; (2) 'his righteous deeds will not be remembered'—metaphor of divine memory/record-keeping; (3) again 'his blood I will require from your hand' idiom as in v.18.

instances.english_text: when I put a stumbling block before them, they shall die
target: God's act of bringing judgment or occasion for fall upon the backsliding righteous
vehicle: placing a stumbling block in someone's path
ground: causing someone to fall to their hurt through an obstacle
means by which a fall/destruction occurs
posture: portrays judgment as both initiated and instrumented by God
instances.explanation: God's judicial action is depicted as placing a block in someone's path so that they trip and perish, conveying the inevitability and instrumentality of judgment.

instances.english_text: their righteous deeds that they did shall not be remembered
target: the status of past righteous acts before God at judgment
divine evaluation of a person's past
ground: to 'remember' is to take into account; to 'forget' is to disregard
keeping or erasing something from the evaluative ledger
posture: underscores seriousness of apostasy despite prior righteousness
stresses present obedience over past record
instances.explanation: God's treatment of deeds is cast in terms of remembering vs. not remembering, using human memory as a metaphor for divine accounting.

instances.english_text: while from you I will require a reckoning for their blood
target: Ezekiel's responsibility for the righteous person's downfall if he fails to warn
vehicle: seeking someone's blood from another's hand
legal demand for a killer's life
ground: treating non-warning as practically equivalent to bloodshed
assigning culpability as if one had killed
posture: heightens the gravity of neglecting warning duties
instances.explanation: As in v.18, God uses forensic 'blood-guilt' language to depict Ezekiel's share in responsibility if he fails to warn.

deliberation: The main figure repeated from v.19 is 'you have saved your life/soul'—idiom of self-preservation from guilt or judgment.

instances.english_text: while you will have saved your own life (saved your soul)
target: Ezekiel's own fate and standing before God
ground: avoiding catastrophic consequences through appropriate action
escaping guilt and its lethal outcome
posture: encourages faithful warning by presenting it as saving oneself
instances.explanation: The idiom 'save your soul' casts Ezekiel's faithful warning as a rescue of his own life from judgment.

deliberation: Again we find 'the hand of the LORD was upon me'—the standard metaphor/idiom for intense divine influence on a prophet.

instances.english_text: Then the hand of the LORD came upon me there
target: the powerful, constraining presence of God on Ezekiel
vehicle: a hand resting strongly upon someone
ground: control, guidance, and pressuring force exerted on a person
being gripped by a superior power
posture: presents prophetic experience as a weighty imposition
instances.explanation: The 'hand' metaphor depicts God's powerful influence resting on the prophet, compelling and directing him.

deliberation: Considered whether the 'glory of the LORD' is figurative; in Ezekiel it is a technical term for the visible manifestation of God's presence. Still, it functions as a metonymy for God himself. No other strong figures beyond standard prostration.

instances.english_text: there stood the Presence (glory) of the LORD
ground: God's manifest presence characterized by radiance and majesty
instances.explanation: The 'glory of the LORD' is a metonym for God's manifest presence, highlighting His majesty rather than naming Him directly.

deliberation: Again 'a spirit entered into me and set me on my feet' personifies the ruach as an agent that can enter and physically raise Ezekiel. The rest is literal command.

instances.english_text: And a spirit entered into me and set me upon my feet
target: Ezekiel's empowerment and readiness to hear and obey
vehicle: a spirit entering and physically raising someone to stand
ground: inner enlivening and enabling to stand before God
instances.explanation: The ruach is personified as entering and setting him on his feet, picturing God's Spirit as the force that restores Ezekiel to active stance.

deliberation: The verse predicts Ezekiel being bound with cords so he cannot go out. While this can be read symbolically in the larger sign-act, the wording itself is literal restraint language with no explicit figurative marker.

The physical description 'I will make your tongue cleave to your palate' prepares for real or visionary muteness; it could be symbolic but is described concretely. 'Rebellious house' is again a metonymic label for the people defined by their rebellion.

instances.english_text: a rebellious breed (rebellious house)
target: Israel as a community characterized by revolt against God
vehicle: household whose defining trait is rebellion
ground: group defined by a persistent characteristic
instances.explanation: Again 'house' is used metonymically for the people, while 'rebellious' names their constitutive trait.

deliberation: Found (1) 'I will open your mouth' as idiom/metaphor for enabling prophetic speech, (2) 'whoever hears will hear and whoever refrains will refrain' as a merism-like pairing covering all responses, and (3) 'rebellious house' again as metonymy.

instances.english_text: I will open your mouth
target: Ezekiel's ability and authorization to speak God's message
ground: granting or withholding the capacity and right to speak
transition from silence to utterance controlled by another
posture: emphasizes God's sovereign control of prophetic speech
instances.explanation: God's promise to 'open' Ezekiel's mouth metaphorically portrays divine enabling and authorization for prophetic proclamation.

instances.english_text: Whoever listens will listen, and whoever does not will not
target: all possible human responses to Ezekiel's message
vehicle: binary pair of listening vs. refraining
posture: highlights inevitability of divergent responses and Ezekiel's limited control
frees the prophet from responsibility for outcomes
instances.explanation: The paired clauses form a merism-like idiom, encompassing all responses and stressing that some will heed and some will refuse.

instances.english_text: a rebellious breed (rebellious house)
ground: group's dominant trait naming the whole
family reputation standing for its members
instances.explanation: Once more 'house' functions as metonym for the people, summarized under the label 'rebellious'.
